saint-john-henry-newman.name: Saint John Henry Newman
saint-john-henry-newman.history: Saint John Henry Newman (1801–1890) was an influential English theologian, philosopher, and Cardinal. Originally an Anglican priest, he was a key figure in the Oxford Movement, advocating for a return to traditional Christian thought and practice. He converted to Catholicism in 1845, eventually becoming a cardinal. His writings on faith, reason, and the development of Christian doctrine continue to be highly influential.

saint-mariam-thresia-chiramel-mankidiyan.name: Saint Mariam Thresia Chiramel Mankidiyan
saint-mariam-thresia-chiramel-mankidiyan.history: Saint Mariam Thresia Chiramel Mankidiyan (1876–1926) was an Indian Syro-Malabar Catholic nun and the founder of the Congregation of the Holy Family. She was known for her intense mystical experiences, including stigmata, and her deep compassion for the poor and marginalized. She dedicated her life to caring for families, the sick, and the dying, establishing schools and homes for the needy.

saint-dulce-lopes-pontes.name: Saint Dulce Lopes Pontes
saint-dulce-lopes-pontes.history: Saint Dulce Lopes Pontes (1914–1992) was a Brazilian Catholic Franciscan Sister. Known as the 'Good Angel of Bahia' and 'Mother Teresa of Brazil,' she dedicated her life to helping the poorest in Salvador, Bahia. She founded numerous charitable works, including a hospital, an orphanage, and a school, often working against great odds and relying on divine providence.

saint-giuseppina-vannini.name: Saint Giuseppina Vannini
saint-giuseppina-vannini.history: Saint Giuseppina Vannini (1859–1911) was an Italian religious sister and the founder of the Daughters of Saint Camillus. Despite a difficult early life, she dedicated herself to serving the sick, especially the terminally ill, through the charism of Saint Camillus de Lellis. Her congregation continues to provide healthcare and compassionate care to those in need worldwide.

saint-marguerite-bays.name: Saint Marguerite Bays
saint-marguerite-bays.history: Saint Marguerite Bays (1815–1879) was a Swiss laywoman, a seamstress by profession, known for her deep piety, humble life, and mystical experiences. She bore the stigmata, though kept it secret, and dedicated herself to prayer, caring for the poor and sick, and catechesis in her local community. She lived a simple, ordinary life with extraordinary faith.
